rounds.response:
Generate Knowledge:
1. Hand Strength: K8s is a borderline hand. Heads-up, being dealt any King-high is above average (you still beat ~50 % of all “random” one-hand ranges), and the suited quality adds ~2 % pre-flop equity. It’s strong enough to defend the big-blind very wide, but still behind a normal “opening range” like any pair, most aces, better Kings, Q9+ etc.
2. Pot Odds & Stack Depth: The small-blind has put the 3-bet in (20), creating pot odds of 30 : 10 = 3:1. We only need 25 % equity to continue (pure MDF math). K8s has ~41 % raw equity vs an average SB 3-bet range, giving us a clear call purely on equity.  
3. Position & Initiative: Post-flop we’ll be out of position. We do not have the betting lead, so unless we improve we’ll often have to play fit-or-fold small-ball post-flop. However, the SPR (stack-to-pot ratio) after a call will be (980-10)/50 ≈ 19.4, which is plenty deep; we can realise more equity than in shallow stacks.
4. Range Morphology: SB risks only 20 to win 30; theory says they should 3-bet wide heads-up (any pair, any ace, any two broadway, most suited connectors). Therefore we should also defend wide – anything inside the top ~65 % of hands qualifies K8s easily.
5. ICM/Survival: No immediate ICM concerns in 10-hand freeze-out—after this hand we’ll be likely navigating with ~1/3–1/4 of the 10 hands yet to play, so small edges compound rather than become ultra-risk-averse. Variance early is acceptable.

Decision: The 10-chip call returns 3:1 with medium-strength equity. Folding is far too tight heads-up. Raising is possible, but out of position with K8s we are bloating the pot without a big equity edge. A simple call lets us realise equity, see the flop cheaply, and preserve the deeper-stack play we possess.

[Call]

rounds.response:
Generate Knowledge:
Pot: 40 chips
Board: Q♣, 8♣, 10♦
My hand: 3♣, J♥

Given the flop, my hand is very weak. I do not have a pair, a straight draw, or a flush draw. The J♥ is an "under-card" to the Q♣. My equity is very low.

Against a single opponent, especially in a small blind vs big blind situation, there are times to bluff, but with a completely missed flop and an opponent who has already shown some strength pre-flop (by calling the small blind's limp or raise, or simply being the big blind), it's generally not advisable to bluff with air.

My immediate options are check or bet. Betting would be a bluff. Checking passes the action to the opponent. Given the weakness of my hand, protecting my stack by folding to future aggression or checking to see a free turn card if the opponent checks behind is the most prudent strategy. I have limited information about my opponent's hand, but it's likely they have something given the board.

Betting here with a super weak hand (air) would be a pure bluff. The chances of getting a fold are low because if the opponent has any piece of the board (a pair of queens, tens, eights, or even a strong draw like a king-jack or ace-king for a straight draw, or two clubs for a flush draw), they will likely call. Our hand has very little equity to improve.

Checking is the default play out of position with a weak hand. It allows me to see what my opponent does. If they bet, I can re-evaluate. If they check, I get a free card.

Decision: Check.

[Check]

Generate Knowledge:
• Strength on this flop: Middle pair (8) with a gut-shot-wheel draw (J9 would complete a king-high straight). Currently we have showdown value but are rarely ahead of a betting range that includes over-pairs, queens, or tens.  
• Two-tone flop (Q♣-8♣-T♦) contains a flush draw; every ♣-suited hand in either range now has at least 9 outs, so we must consider future aggression.  
• Position: As the big blind / on the button, we act last; this allows pot control or bluff catching and makes checking behind weaker showdown hands favorable.  
• SPR (Stack-to-Pot Ratio) ≈ 980 / 40 ≈ 24 (“deep stack” territory). Mistakes here cost big chunks of our tournament life—but also provide maneuvering space.  
• Bet-size theory: When deciding whether to bet for protection/ thin value we risk forcing out worse hands (bluffs, Ace-high) while building a pot we rarely improve on turn/river. Without significant fold equity, betting small or checking to realize equity is better.  
• Mental game: Early in a 10-hand mini-match we want to build a tight-aggressive image first; over-folding flop when we have middle pair + outs keeps our calling credible later.  
• Line consideration: Check → we keep in all bluffs and can reevaluate turn; Probe-bet → folds out ace-high and pocket 2-7 (thin profit) but faces check-raise semi-bluffs and has reverse implied odds.

Evaluation of Options:
1. Check behind: Safely realize turn/river equity, pot control, avoid turning our hand into a bluff. Keeps pot small when behind a queen or set.  
2. Bet sizing: With the drawy texture, a bet between 20–30 seems typical; however we have showdown value vs bricked ranges and the fold equity on a bet is uncertain.  
3. Raise/fold lines not possible as no bet is live; checking is the default if we decline to bet.

Decision:
We have marginal showdown value and need cards to fall our way; we cannot profitably charge draws large, so we keep the pot small and act with information.

[Check]

Target weak single pairs, missed straight draws, or naked A-high hands that have checked twice. Bet small for value / protection.

Decision – open a standard heads-up steal.

Generate Knowledge:
My current hand is A heart 10 spade. This is a decent starting hand, especially for a short-handed game. An Ace is a strong card, and suited connectors or a high card with a decent kicker can often be played.
However, I am out of position (SB) and facing a bet from the dealer/BB. They have the positional advantage throughout the hand.
Given the blinds are 10/20, my current bet is 20 chips, and the pot is 30.
I have 950 chips remaining. P0 has 1020 chips.
In previous hands, P0 has been aggressive, often winning by folding. I've been relatively passive.

Options:
1.  **Call 10:** This keeps the pot small and allows me to see the flop cheaply. With A-10, I can hit a good flop. However, I'll be out of position for the rest of the hand.
2.  **Raise:** Raising pre-flop with A-10 can accomplish a few things:
    *   Pot control: If P0 folds, I win the blinds.
    *   Value: If P0 calls, it builds the pot with a decent hand.
    *   Information: P0's reaction (call, re-raise, fold) gives me an idea of their hand strength.
    *   Strength representation: A raise will represent a stronger hand than a call.
3.  **Fold:** Folding is an option if I believe my hand isn't strong enough or if P0 is likely to re-raise aggressively, putting me in a difficult spot. However, A-10 suited is generally too strong to fold pre-flop from the SB when only facing the BB.

Considering the A-10s, it's a hand that can flop well (top pair, two pair, flush draw). Being out of position is a disadvantage, so trying to gain control of the pot or get P0 to fold early can be beneficial. Given P0's recent aggressive play (multiple wins by folding from me), a raise here could be a good counter-strategy to show resistance and potentially take down the pot immediately or with a strong flop. A standard raise would be to 3-4x the current bet, so to 60-80 chips. Given I've been relatively passive, a raise here might be effective.
However, raising to 40 would be a smaller, less committal raise if I want to just test the waters or if P0 has been folding to small raises. A larger raise (e.g., to 60 or 80) would put more pressure on P0.

Let's go for a standard raise to build the pot and assert some aggression. A raise to 60 (3x my current bet) feels appropriate.
[Raise 60]

Generate Knowledge (Heads-Up Pre-flop Defense, 30bb+ stacks, I’m in the BB facing a 4× raise)

1. Pot odds vs 3-bet folds  
   Calling 70 into a final pot of 200 = 35 % raw equity threshold.  
   T5o typically has ~36 % vs a 45 %-open → mathematically barely sufficient.
2. Reverse implied odds / domination  
   5-high unsuited connects weakly; TP hands (T-5-x-x-x) tends to be dominated (T9s, AT, KT, QT, JT).  Open-ender possibilities are small (need 6789 or 678x) and never the nut straight.
3. 3-bet alternative  
   - Effective stacks 1020 : 890 ≈ 51 bb each → plenty of room.  
   - T5o is outside my top ~10 % 3-bet bluff range (K5s, J9s, 87s etc rate higher). Using it as 3-bluff bloats pot OOP with still mediocre equity; better to 3-bet polarized.
4. Post-flop playability  
   When we do flop a 5 we often only have 2nd or 3rd pair and OOP on later streets.  
   Missing the flop is common and invite c-bet pressure.
5. Momentum & image vs opponent tendencies  
   I have picked up small uncontested pots three times in the last six hands. Villain just now changed gears with the first 4-raise; this increase is proportional and does not yet scream aggression. Folding keeps my range honest and stack controliel.

Applying the knowledge → we do not meet the quality threshold to continue with a dominated, off-suit hand OOP. Folding preserves future fold equity.

[Fold]

Generate Knowledge:

Current Situation: Early into a 10-hand heads-up match (Hand 8/10). I am Small-Blind; blinds 10/20. I hold 8♥ 10♣, effective stacks 50 BB (1000 vs 970). No pre-flop action yet.

Key principles for heads-up poker with marginal holdings:

1. Heads-up hand ranges widen dramatically. Almost any two cards can be played profitably in position, and many hands are playable OOP. Suited/connected hands gain significant value.

2. Stack-to-pot ratio is ~32 (20/40 to play). A raise here keeps SPR high, so future streets remain playable.

3. Hand potential: 8♥ 10♣ is J-high suited one-gapper (often referred to as T8s). It flops gut-shots (97x), 2BDFD (hearts), weak top-pairs, and straight-draws, giving dependable equity.

4. Positional disadvantage: As SB I am out of position post-flop. Rely on aggressive 2.5-3.5 BB raise to take control, reduce opponent’s positional edge.

5. Fold equity: Opponent (P1) checked pre-flop but has demonstrated willingness to fold to early aggression (folded to our flop bet in Hand 1, pre-flop folds past few hands). Light 3-bet by villain once (hand 7) is still uncommon.

6. Balancing: From SB, mixing open-raises (2 variants: 3× and 2.2×) plus occasional limp keeps range unexploitable. Here we opt for standard raise.

Calculation: Raise to 60 (3 BB) risks 60 to win 30, so needs 60 / (60 + 30) = 66.7 % fold equity to profit immediately. Given villain’s current leak, this is reasonable, and we have playable equity when called or 3-bet.

Decision:

[Bet 60]
